content.body: jmdyck: I'll defer to annevk on that. He's been the one who loves that particular bit of consistency.
content.formatted_body: jmdyck: I'll defer to annevk on that. He's been the one who loves that particular bit of consistency.

content.body: jmdyck: I would r+ it. What might be tricky is not violating the wrapping rules at the same time. And there's also some cases where we don't want it. E.g., "Otherwise, if ..., bar" should not be "then bar".
content.formatted_body: jmdyck: I would r+ it. What might be tricky is not violating the wrapping rules at the same time. And there's also some cases where we don't want it. E.g., "Otherwise, if ..., bar" should not be "then bar".

annevk: Hm, not familiar with "r+".
Re "What might be tricky is not violating the wrapping rules at the same time." Isn't the solution just to re-wrap?
Re "And there's also some cases where we don't want it. E.g., "Otherwise, if ..., bar" should not be "then bar"." Why don't you want it there?
"r+" means "I approve"
thx
where does it come from?
jmdyck: maybe Bugzilla reviewing culture? Could predate that. I don't actually know.
content.formatted_body: jmdyck: maybe Bugzilla reviewing culture? Could predate that. I don't actually know.

content.body: For "Otherwise, if ..." it reads weird (to me). But we omit it for "Otherwise" in general so it's somewhat consistent.
(Looks like "r+" means "rated up" at reddit)
We also started omitting "then" when it precedes substeps.
I should fix that case in Infra I guess.

I'm thinking about it from the viewpoint of parsing algorithms. Having the "then" keyword makes it easier (possible) to detect the end of the condition. But if there are cases like "Otherwise, if" where it's not going to be there, then the parser needs to be able to detect the end of the condition without "then", so inserting "then"s is less valuable to me.

* I'm thinking about it from the viewpoint of parsing algorithms. Having the "then" keyword makes it easier (possible) to detect the end of the condition. But if there are cases like "Otherwise, if" where it's not going to be there, then the parser needs to be able to detect the end of the condition without "then" anyway, so inserting "then"s is less valuable to me.

m.new_content.body: I'm thinking about it from the viewpoint of parsing algorithms. Having the "then" keyword makes it easier (possible) to detect the end of the condition. But if there are cases like "Otherwise, if" where it's not going to be there, then the parser needs to be able to detect the end of the condition without "then" anyway, so inserting "then"s is less valuable to me.

content.body: There's not a lot of "Otherwise, if" since we prefer early returns, but there are some. If that's your goal you might get more mileage out of rewriting algorithms that use labels and goto and typically use a much older editorial style.
labels and goto are easy-ish to parse though.
`grep -c 'Otherwise, if' source` says 196, btw
(and a good fraction of them have "then" too)
Hmm, maybe it should be okay? I guess I could be persuaded. It doesn't read too bad in the hidden setter steps for instance.
"r+" dates back to when people reviewed on bugzilla by changing the "review" field from "?" to "+" or "-", hence "r(eview)+" and "r(eview)-"
Looks like ~80% of "Otherwise, if" have "then" or a colon after the condition.
jmdyck: fair enough. Let's settle on that then.
content.formatted_body: jmdyck: fair enough. Let's settle on that then.

content.body: Which I guess makes the rule that an if statement is terminated by ", then" or ":", which seems pretty good.
ok, thanks.
I've also got some questions about (meta-) terminology. E.g., consider a navigable. The spec doesn't say what kind of thing it is. Is it reasonable to consider it a 'struct' in the Infra sense?
Or do you think of it as a different kind of thing?
Do structs have identity?
Hm, Infra doesn't talk about identity.
